ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PUBLIC UTILITIES BOARD
(Single-meter single-tariff system for power and lighting)


    1. Mr Low Yong Nguan asked the Prime Minister if he will ascertain from the Public Utilities Board whether the Board plans to introduce a single-meter

Column: 48

single-tariff system for both power and lighting consumption, and when the system can be expected to be introduced.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Lim Kim San) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply on behalf of the Prime Minister as I am directly involved with the Public Utilities Board. To answer the first question, I would say that Singapore is still saddled with the antiquated system of wiring and metering separately for

Column: 49

lighting and power. If we change over to a single-meter system, which does not differentiate between lighting and power, it would mean a saving in the cost of wiring and metering. So we have asked a firm of consultants to advise us on the changing over to this system of single metering. They will present their report soon to the Public Utilities Board. It is hoped to introduce the single-meter system of electricity tariffs to the general Public as soon as it is conveniently possible.

Column: 49

PUBLIC UTILITIES BOARD
(Electricity Code)


    2. Mr Low Yong Nguan asked the Prime Minister if he would ascertain from the Public Utilities Board whether the Board plans to introduce its own Electricity Code to suit local requirements.

    Mr Lim Kim San (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Electricity Department of the Public Utilities Board has compiled two draft sets of electricity regulations - (i) Licensing and Safety Regulations for Electrical Installations and (ii) Electricity Supply Regulations. The Licensing and Safety Regulations for Electrical Installations cover safety standards for electrical installations and the operation, repair and maintenance of such installations, the licensing and registration of private generators, the registration of electrical contractors, the colour coding for electrical appliances, the approval of electrical apparatus and other related matters. The Electricity Supply Regulations set out general rules concerning applications for electricity supplies.

    The draft regulations now under review will shortly be presented to the Public Utilities Board for approval before enactment under the Public Utilities Act.

    Mr Low Yong Nguan (Crawford): Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister inform the House whether there has been consultation with the relevant

Column: 50

professional bodies in the drafting of regulations before such a draft is finally accepted?

    Mr Lim Kim San: I am sure there has been consultation with the professional bodies. However, if the Member will let me know what professional body he has in mind, and if we find that they have a standing in their profession, we will certainly try to get their views oil the legislation that will be enacted.

Column: 50

PUBLIC UTILITIES BOARD
(Results of salary consolidation exercise)


    3. Mr Low Yong Nguan asked the Prime Minister (a) if he will ascertain from the Public Utilities Board (i) how many officers of the Board have had their take-home pay reduced in the recent salary consolidation exercise; and (ii) how many officers have had to pay arrears to the Municipal Provident Fund in excess of their monthly salary; and (b) if he is satisfied that as a result of the exercise there have been improvement and simplification in the salary structures.

    Mr Lim Kim San (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, the exercise on consolidation of salaries was to integrate the basic salary with the variable allowance into an all-in salary; in other words, what were allowances before have now been incorporated into the salary proper. As donation and contribution to the Provident Fund will be based on the consolidated salary, some 1,389 out of a total of 2,756 officers will have their take-home pay reduced. There is, however, an increase in the gross emoluments drawn by these officers because of the larger amount of donation made by the Board to the Provident Fund. For the 30-month period from 1st January, 1969, the total increase in the Board's donation to Provident Fund would amount lo 51,350,700, averaging about $40,000 a month.

Column: 51



    Some 79 out of 839 officers who ate members of the Municipal Provident Fund have to pay arrears in excess of their monthly-consolidated salaries to the Fund covering the 30-month period. However, they have the option to pay these arrears in one lump sum or by 12 monthly instalments.

    The result of the exercise on consolidation has been a reduction of 88 basic salary scales of senior, junior and subordinate officers grades to 25 key scales.

    With the consolidation of salaries, emoluments drawn by the staff are based on services rendered, irrespective of sex or marital status, a principle recommended by the Harvey Commission and accepted by Government.

    The improvement in salary and salary structure is reflected by the fact that 93.1 per cent of monthly paid staff, (that is, 2,756 out of 2,961 officers) have opted to accept the new consolidated salaries.

    Mr Low Yong Nguan: Sir, in the case of officers opting to pay their arrears to the Municipal Provident Fund in instalments, can the Minister let us know whether interest has been added for paying such arrears in instalments?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, we do not believe in giving anything f tee. We are charging six per cent interest on the loan. This is cheaper than they can get anywhere.

    Mr Low Yong Nguan: The point is this. The arrears have been accumulated not because of the fault of the officers, it is due to the delay in the implementation of the consolidation which was recommended some two and a half years ago. Therefore, how can the P.U.B, justify its action in adding interest to the arrears which should have been paid long ago if they had been more efficient in their consolidation exercise?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, the consolidation exercise did not depend upon one party. It was arrived at and

Column: 52

agreed upon after long negotiations with the officers. So if the P.U.B, is to be blamed, then I say the officers are to be equally blamed. On the whole, they gain; they do not lose. As I have pointed out, the Public Utilities Board is out of pocket by about $40,000 a month. Let me tell the Member here that if I had my way, it would not have been backdated to 1st January 1969. It is just because the Board made an error in promising the staff that consolidation would be backdated to 1st January 1969. The question of backdating is one on which I hold very strong views indeed.

    Mr Low Yong Nguan: There should have been no backdating, Sir.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, an option was given to the officers whether to accept consolidation or not. Whether it should be backdated to 1st January, 1969, or not is something which was forced on me. I would say that most of the P.U.B, officers supported backdating. They wanted it to be backdated because they would gain in the long run. Consolidation, in the majority of cases, means an increase in total emoluments though the take-home pay would be less. If I had known earlier that the Member would prefer not to have it back-dated to 1st January 1969, I would have conscripted his services and probably the P.U.B, could have saved quite a lot of money.

    Mr Low Yong Nguan: If the P.U.B, had been more efficient in getting the correct views, Sir, ---

    Mr Speaker: Is the Member asking a supplementary question?

    Mr Low Yong Nguan: No, Sir.

Column: 52

NATIONAL SERVICE
(Particulars of applications for deferment)


    4. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister of Defence how many applications for deferment of National Service have been received since January, 1971, and how many of them have been (i)

Column: 53

approved, and the circumstances for which approval was given; and (ii) rejected.

    The Minister of Defence (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Sir, a total of 189 applications for deferment of full-time national service were received from 1st January, 1971, to 16th July, 1971. Applications for deferment generally fall under three main categories: namely, (1) social or financial hardship; (2) business disintegration; and (3) in the case of Government employees or employees of statutory boards, the exigencies of the service.

    Fifty-four applications were approved on grounds of social or financial hardship, and 17 were rejected. Thirty-two applications were approved on grounds of business disintegration, and 22 were rejected. Forty-three applications received on grounds of the exigencies of the service were approved, while 21 were rejected.

Column: 53

PUBLIC BUS SERVICE REORGANISATION
(Complaints of dissatisfaction and steps to improve situation)


    5. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Communications, (a) since the reorganisation of the public bus service, how many complaints of dissatisfaction over bus services have been received by his Ministry from members of the public, and whether the complaints have been dealt with immediately; and (h) whether he is aware that there are irregular departures of buses from bus termini with the result that it takes half an hour before the next bus arrives at a bus-stop or that several buses bearing the same service number arrive at the same time, and what steps he has taken to improve the situation.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir:(a) As a result of the recent bus services reorganisation, the number of written complaints received by the Suggestions Action Unit (P.O. Box 6000) of the Ministry, which was set up on

Column: 54

5th March, 1971, more than a month before the reorganisation, was 348.

    These, however, included 65 letters which were anonymous, that is, without name or address, thus making it impossible for our Ministry to acknowledge or to follow up on them.

    The remaining 283 letters, of which 226 were in English, 49 in Chinese and eight in Tamil, were first acknowledged by the Ministry and the complainants were subsequently advised of the remedial decisions that were taken; whether they were found acceptable, as proposed, or acceptable after suitable amendments had been made, or not acceptable but with reasons therefor, etc.

    It may interest the Member for Sembawang if I give him some indication of the nature of the complaints received. They may be classified broadly as follows:

		                                  complaints

  (ii)  Dissatisfaction over no direct service        78             

 (iii)  Poor or irregular frequecy                    78 

  (iv)  Bus fares                                     19

  (vi)  Complaints regarding routes being too

          long and circuitous                         10

          (first bus/last bus leaving terminal)        9

                                                     300

Column: 55



    As we dealt with 283 letters, of course, some letters of complaint did contain more than one type of complaint.

    (b) Regarding the irregular departure of buses from bus termini resulting in irregular and poor frequency along the routes, the Bus Services Licensing Authority, as well as the Registry of Vehicles, are fully aware of this perennial problem, which occurs whenever there is poor management control over the bus drivers or because of traffic congestion upsetting bus schedules. To counter this, the Bus Services Licensing Authority requires all bus companies to furnish to the Authority a Performance Bond of $100,000 per company, under the new Bus Services Licensing Authority Act, which came into operation on 1st March 1971. Any company, which is found to be giving poor services, without any good reason, is liable to a financial penalty deductible from the Performance Bond. The staff of the Investigation Section of the R.O.V., which is being strengthened, will keep observation over the performance of the bus companies by conducting routine checks, or on receipt of complaints from the public, to ensure that the bus companies do provide a more regular and efficient service than what was available prior to the bus services reorganisation in April this year.

Column: 55

PRIMARY I ENROLMENT IN
CHINESE SCHOOLS IN JULY 1971
(Particulars)


    6. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Minister for Education (a) how many children have been enrolled in Primary I classes in Chinese schools in July 1971, and in how many schools; and (b) whether he is considering extending the new system of enrolment to schools in the other language streams.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, altogether 1,190 children have been enrolled in Primary I classes in July 1971, in 23 Government and Government-Aided Chinese primary and full schools.

Column: 56



    As the system of having two Primary I intakes a year is a pilot project, evaluation will have to be made in due course in order to determine the desirability of extending this system to other language streams, bearing in mind the limitation of resources with regard to physical facilities and teaching staff.

Column: 56

FOREIGN UNDESIRABLE PUBLICATIONS
(Measures to stop circulation)


    7. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Culture what measures have been taken against the circulation of foreign undesirable publications, which are poisoning the minds of our young children.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr Jek Yeun Thong): Mr Speaker, Sir, by "foreign undesirable publications", I presume the Member for Thomson has in mind the Chinese chain comic books imported mainly from Hongkong. These books, as you can see from the samples here, are poor in quality, crude in production and seem to contain nothing except violence, bloodshed, ghosts and demons, and even sex. We consider them to be very harmful to the young children and have always been trying to slop them from being imported into Singapore. Our methods include Post Office and Customs interceptions and periodic surprise raids on bookshops known to be specialising in this kind of comic books. I myself have personally made appeals to the Singapore Chinese Booksellers' Association to restrain their members from importing such books. But there are always the black sheep in the flock. We have tried several ways to stop them, but they are always one up on us. I presume the profit that they derive from selling such books must be quite substantial.

    Moreover, our criteria on these books are different from those in Malaysia. This difference has been exploited by the operators in recent months. They first import the books quite openly into Malaysia and then smuggle them into Singapore through our Woodlands

Column: 57

check-point where we had no inspector to check on book parcels. However, since March this year, measures have been taken to remedy this. Since then, more than l9,000 copies of these books have been confiscated and destroyed.

    We will continue to keep a close watch on these operators and, if necessary, very stern action will be taken against them. But this alone is not enough. We want the help of parents, teachers and the civic-minded public. They should report to us whenever they find these books being sold in the bookshops.

Column: 57

BUILDING OPERATIONS AND WORKS OF ENGINEERING
CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS


2.56 p.m.

    The Minister of State for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move the motion standing in the

Column: 59

name of the Minister for Labour, namely,

    That this Parliament, pursuant to subsection (3) of section 66 of the Factories Act (Chapter 123, 1970 Edition), resolves that the Building Operations and Works of Engineering Construction Regulations, 1971, made on the 18th day of March, 1971, and published as Notification No. S 96 in the Gazette Subsidiary Legislation Supplement No. 21 of 26th March, 1971, as contained in Paper S.L. 16 of 1971, be approved.

    Sir, over the past few years, my Ministry has been very perturbed and greatly concerned at the steady rise in the number of accidents occurring in the building and engineering construction industry. Statistics show that 279 accidents occurred in the industry in 1969, and in 1970 this figure rose to 376, a rise of nearly 35 per cent.

    In the first six months of 1971, reports of 166 accidents have been received. What is even more tragic is the number of persons killed as a result of these accidents. In 1969, 17 persons were reported killed in the building and engineering construction industry. In 1970 it was 19. Until June this year, nine fatal accidents have been reported.

    The above figures illustrate the urgent need for the adoption of higher standards of safety measures in the building and engineering construction industry. But experience has shown that mere exhortations and appeals to the goodwill of the employers and the good sense of the workers to be more safety conscious have been of little avail. My Ministry is therefore of the view that definite guidelines are necessary. The Regulations now before the House not only strengthen the provisions of the Factories Act relating to the health, safety and welfare of the workers, but also provide for safety measures of special application to the building and engineering construction industry. The cardinal principle enunciated in these Regulations is that the required safety measures for any project or construction work should be incorporated right from the design stage and not left to be added on as an afterthought or when accidents

Column: 60

have already occurred. The basic provisions for safety should therefore be `i major consideration at all stages and levels of planning and implementation.

    The Regulations also stress the need for qualified and competent persons to erect or set up the requisite safety measures and to make frequent inspections to ensure that these are properly maintained and correctly used. The Regulations not only require the employer to provide safe working conditions but also make it the duty of every employee to co-operate in carrying out the Regulations.

    It is hoped that with the implementation of these comprehensive, unequivocal and stringent Regulations, workers in the building and construction industry will enjoy a greater measure of safety at their working places and also enjoy a higher standard of health.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

3.02 p.m.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is all very well to have all the rules and regulations, but how about their enforcement? I think the Factory Inspectorate is not adequately staffed. I am just wondering what is the latest position regarding the staffing of the Factory Inspectorate. Will the Minister please inform the House?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker. Sir, at the last sitting of Parliament, if I remember correctly indications were given that a special Establishment Warrant would be issued to get the necessary staff. I am glad to say that that has already been done, and that almost all the vacancies sc established have been filled.

3.04 p.m.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Mr Speaker, Sir, industrialisation and the process of construction have attendant hazards. In Singapore, industrialisation and construction work are going on

Column: 61

rapidly. The consequence of a disregard of the safety rules to achieve a target is the cause of the rising number of industrial accidents in recent times. This is recognised in the President's speech. I am particularly happy to make an observation of the introduction of the Building Operations and Works of Engineering Construction Regulations which would provide, among other things, comprehensive measures and requirements designed to safeguard the health and safety of workers at the building and engineering construction work sites. These Regulations are most necessary and timely. As is recognised by the Government, the number of accidents in this particular field has been the highest. It can be expected that in the race against time to complete building projects, the accident rate in this area will increase. For instance, the competition among hoteliers to be the first to catch the tourists has caused the people concerned in the building project to disregard all safety rules and precautions necessary for the safety of the workers.

    There was, for example, an instance at the Mandarin Hotel construction site where two men fell to their death within a short space of time. After the first death, the workers asked for some safety measures to be taken. Their request fell on deaf ears. After the second fall, the workers stopped work. No one could blame them for the stoppage. In fact, with so much disregard for safety by the contractors. I think we could well have some more stoppages. We could not blame the workers for their militancy in this respect. In this regard, when a trench wall collapsed at the construction site of Chartered Industries I think this is a company owned by the Government a worker was buried and killed by an avalanche. The workers downed tools, they said, as a mark of respect for their dead colleague. I think it is not only good wages and bonuses that the workers should be concerned with, but also their safety and health. Therefore, safety and health standards must be maintained at the highest possible

Column: 62

level, and the introduction of these Regulations is most welcome to the National Trades Union Congress though the workers in the building and construction field are not organised. In this regard, I think the Chief Inspector of Factories should pay some particular attention to reduce the safety hazards, which the workers face day by day. It is immaterial whether they are citizens or non-citizens. There are some 10.000 citizens, I believe, who are engaged in construction work. For humanitarian reasons, I think more attention should be paid to reduce the safety hazards, which the workers in the engineering construction field face.

    I would like to make another point. Attempts should be made to correct attitudes towards the question of safety. We can find one thousand and one excuses to ignore safety hazards. Among the excuses there is one quite commonly given when a rational answer cannot be found to a problem whether it is in respect of culture or safety - that it is our Asian way of life. I think we could well profit by adopting some Western habits. There was one incident, which comes to my mind. When I was in Canada in 1963, as a V.I.P., I was brought to a construction site because the union boss there wanted to show me the pride of his town. My host took me to inspect the showpiece of his union. Hardly had we been in the building for five minutes when I heard a loud voice shouting like "Get out" several times. My host, the union boss tried to explain to the foreman, "We have a V.I.P.". That explanation was totally disregarded. He was shouted down and practically abused. We got out of the building. After he had cooled down, the foreman heard the union boss' explanation. Very politely, he brought us in after he had ordered some helmets for us. This is the kind of attitude which foremen or mandores engaged by contractors in our own building and construction site; should have. Unfortunately, they have not.

    All I can say is that the N.T.U.C, welcome these Regulations. We have made a study of them and I think we

Column: 63

could have a period of experimentation, and, if need be, make the necessary amendments as a result of experience.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am in entire agreement with the sentiments expressed by the Member for Kallang. I think the staff of the Ministry of Labour, like any other citizen or non-citizen for that matter, is aware of the importance of measures to save lives and of preventing accidents happening anywhere.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Resolved,

    That this Parliament, pursuant to subsection (3) of section 66 of the Factories Act (Chapter 123, 1970 Edition), resolves that the Building Operations and Works of Engineering Construction Regulations, 1971, made on the 18th day of March, 1971, and published as Notification No. S 96 in the Gazette Subsidiary Legislation Supplement No. 21 of 26th March, 1971, as contained in Paper S.L. 16 of 1971, be approved.

NATURE RESERVES ORDINANCE
(MODIFICATION OF SCHEDULE)


3.12 p.m.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker. Sir, I beg to move the motion* standing in my name as it appears on the Order Paper.

    Sir, in order to provide our citizens with additional facilities for recreational purposes, the Public Utilities Board is developing parts of the catchment areas of MacRitchie and Seletar Reservoirs into public parks. In fact, hundreds of people visit these reservoirs during week-days and thousands during weekends. As parts of these catchment areas form part of the Natute Reserves, it is necessary to delete these areas from the Schedule to the Nature Reserves Ordinance in the manner provided under section 4 thereof. Hence the motion.

    The President began his speech with these words: "After six years of separate independence, we have shown that Singapore is viable."

    Those words constitute a simple statement of fact.

    There were many who were saddened by the separation of our country from Malaysia six years ago. Our leaders and people then knew that the road ahead as an independent and sovereign Republic of Singapore would be a hard one. They must today look back with considerable satisfaction on what has

Column: 67

been achieved. Characteristically, however, because of the sterner stuff of which they are made, our people seek still higher performance from themselves for our country.

    As our President observed, we want the quality of life to go up. The more well-to-do have homes in the many fine housing estates and blocks of luxury flats that abound in our island.

    I have no doubt whatsoever that our people will defend what they have created and what they own.

    I am also confident that I speak for all Members in this House that we will not be deflected from our course towards a modern, multiracial, democratic and industrialized island-nation.

    Three years ago, the debate following the speech of our late President Yusof Bin Ishak was sombre. We faced many problems then, for the British Government had decided to accelerate their military withdrawal. The Member for Nee Soon on that occasion spoke about maintaining a rate of growth of Gross Domestic Product of eight per cent. There must have been many at that time, academic economists included those adherents of that dismal science - who must have thought him an incorrigible optimist. But his confidence

Column: 68

in the will and determination of our people was well founded. If today that Honourable Member were to predict the same rate of growth of eight per cent for our economy, which I am sure he will not, he would be suspected of being a congenital pessimist.

In America, a huge country, with hundreds of universities and colleges, a riot at any one of them is a local problem.

    I would therefore urge our intellectuals to be more realistic and to have greater perspective. They should not be so ready to hurl accusations of dictatorship and label our society a closed society. People who do, remind me forcefully of the fable of the boy who cried "wolf" when there was none, and nobody heeded him when a wolf finally came and devoured him. Our intellectuals should visit countries where democracy does not exist to see the vital differences for themselves.

Column: 83



    As we develop, our level of literacy and intellectual sophistication will grow. People will ask more searching, more substantive questions of their leaders. We must learn to adjust to one another. Political leaders will need not only to have substance in their programmes but will be expected to have appropriate style as well. Intellectuals outside the political arena must be constructive and realistic if they wish to be taken seriously. They should remember that the problems they perceive, though real and seemingly urgent, may lose priority to bigger ones they do not see within their horizon.

    To effect a proper and rational dialogue, the press must play its part responsibly. The habit of slanting reports or putting an angle to a story make sensational headlines and presumably interest more readership. By doing so, however, reporters and editors do public figures grave injustice and damage. Politicians are always subject to scrutiny and what they say is always discounted with some scepticism. The least that they deserve is accurate coverage. I, for one, do not mind any amount of criticism, provided my views are recorded accurately. I consider it highly unethical, if not mischievous and cowardly, to distort anybody's views and then to criticize, especially in pseudonymous columns. Let it be known to such people that I am always ready to debate with them publicly and fairly anywhere.

    What kind of society do we want- a society where everyone, regardless of race or other distinguishing characteristics, can have equality of opportunity, a decent job, a decent home and clean surroundings, or one where people suffer discrimination, talk in hushed whispers and walk the streets in fear? From time to time the under-currents of intolerance emerge in the columns of our newspapers. Not too long ago, for example, there were a spate of letters from readers discussing the appropriate use or non-use of non-Chinese names by Chinese. Do we want a society where we measure the worth of a man by the

Column: 84

kind of name he has, or by the way he writes his name? I do not want such a society, and, if it comes to be, I do not want my children and grandchildren to live in it.

    We are a small country, Sir, but limited though we are by lack of land and other natural resources, there is no limit to the economic heights that we can attain, provided we organize ourselves properly and peacefully to acquire the necessary skills and to apply the ingenuity of our people. With economic affluence we shall have plenty of room for cultural development. There will, in other words, be plenty of room for all of us and our children and grandchildren provided we are willing to be tolerant and understanding.

    With firm and fair government, we are doing well. Our economy is flourishing and will continue to flourish provided we are able to project enough confidence to the investor, whether local or foreign, so that he will build his factory to provide the jobs we need. Our standard of living will rise in two stages. In the initial stage we earn higher wages by learning more skills as technicians, engineers, managers and marketing personnel. Then, when our economy grows richer, even those with no skills can have a higher standard of living because we shall be able to afford it collectively.

    The basic organisation of our economy, given the peculiar conditions we have, is necessarily based on a capitalistic, free enterprise system. Government policy, at present and in the immediate future, has to be geared towards providing the infrastructure and the inducements to stimulate economic activity. There is a danger that, in pursuing these necessary objectives, we may produce large numbers of technocrats and bureaucrats with no social compassion or sensitivity. From time to time, therefore, we need to remind ourselves of our socialistic aims of a more equal and more just society. We need to give adequate thought to the problems of the poor, the weak, the disabled and the displaced. Sometimes policy measures, though economically and socially indispensable, bear harshly on certain

Column: 85

sectors. In this respect, I greatly welcome the Government's move to increase compensation for the resettlement of farmers and shopkeepers and others affected by urban renewal. Our national welfare can rightly be considered to have improved if, and only if, those who are made better off do so not at the expense of others, or, if they do, there is adequate and fair compensation. The poorer classes should, as a matter of firm principle, never be made to pay for economic or social development unless they themselves are clear beneficiaries in the end.

    In a society where the great majority of people are poor and oppressed, there is yet hope of redress via a revolution, because intelligent, if not developed, leadership exists among them. However, in a modern, technological society, where much of the brainpower has emerged into the upper and controlling strata of society, the poor have neither political power via the voting booth, nor articulate leadership among their ranks. In a developed society, clearly the political leadership must avoid the hegemony of the middle and upper income classes if the poor people are to get a fair deal.

    Let us, therefore, work for a society in Singapore where, on the one hand, people are rewarded and promoted on strict merit, and, on the other, ample opportunities are afforded to those who are hampered by poverty. In other words, let us build not merely a society based only on meritocracy, but let us have a meritocracy-plus society.

    One of the key measures available to a government in a democratic country to promote greater equality is the judicious use of the tax system. I think it is time we had a comprehensive review of our system of taxation to achieve more socialism without hurting efficiency. Certain taxes are inherently regressive, that is, they bear on people who can least afford them. I am concerned about the incidence of such taxes as taxes on P.U.B, bills, for example. Although the tax is graduated with a higher tax on bigger bills, poor people with large families and therefore, using more utilities are adversely affected.

Column: 86



    I think there should also be taxes to discourage lavish consumption. The reasons for advocating such taxes are both economic and socialistic. A widening income gap between rich and poor is inevitable in a society with rapid development, unless there is government intervention. In the first place, low-income people can be given greater earning power through education and training. We can justify the rich having more, provided most of the accretion goes into further investment to provide more jobs. If, instead, it goes into lavish consumption, then the Government should introduce taxes to take some of it away to be spent on the poor. Moreover, if lavish consumption is not controlled or discouraged, the demonstration effect may be upsetting to poorer people and may affect their motivation to work and to save adversely. The Government, therefore, should seriously consider heavy excise taxes on luxury-type cars, luxury-type flats, houses, and so on.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like next to comment on the programmes for a number of Ministries.

    My first comment is in reference to the development of higher education which comes within the purview of the Ministry of Science and Technology. I am wondering if the Minister concerned has in mind an optimal size for a university. Sir, administration becomes difficult and impersonal when the student population glows too big.

    Moreover, there are always dissidents in any group, but in a large congregation the absolute number of such people becomes significant and can lead to the kind of student unrest we see in western countries.

    It may, therefore, be more desirable to increase the number of universities rather than have fewer large ones.

    The Addendum to the Ministry of Labour lists a number of important new policies. In addition, perhaps the Minister for Labour may want to consider the status of daily-rated workers in Government departments and statutory bodies, Can anything be

Column: 87

done to, perhaps, give them more regularity or permanency in employment? Would the Minister also look into the reorganisation of the Employment Exchange in order to provide a better picture of the unemployment situation so that better placement of people can be effected, and perhaps upgrading of local skills can be facilitated? The Minister may also want to consider opening other `employment exchanges to improve the process of placing people into desired jobs.

    Sir, I now turn to the Ministry of Health, especially with respect to hawkers. The allocation of $5 million to build new hawker centres is a very welcome move. Hawking provides jobs for unskilled and uneducated people, especially widows, older people and people affected by resettlement. It is an important social welfare supplement, and hence a very important social safety valve. It is important in keeping down the cost of living. Moreover, it is potentially a good tourist attraction. There should be efforts made to help improve health and cooking standards.

    The Minister may also wish to look into the matter of better collaboration with the Hawkers' Section of the Housing and Development Board. There is one particular anomaly, which adversely affects hawkers under the Housing and Development Board's jurisdiction. This relates to the obligation of the Housing and Development Board to pay property tax of 36 per cent a year, which thereby raises the fees payable by its hawkers. Those hawker centres which are managed by the Ministry of Health are exempt from property tax. I would appeal to the Minister for Health to subsidize the Housing and Development Board on the property tax on hawker centres so as to reduce the licence fees payable by these hawkers and make things more equitable.

    Sir, I now wish to raise two matters relating to the Ministry of Finance. Sometime in April this year, on my return from a trade mission to Japan,

Column: 88

I made a number of recommendations in respect of export promotion and financing. Perhaps the Minister for Finance will inform this House in due course what steps, if any, are being taken.

    Sir, the major thrust of the Government industrialization programme has been towards the encouragement of foreign investment. While the emphasis is correct, if we are to acquire the technological sophistication, the managerial and marketing know-how in the shortest possible time, I think that with full employment in sight, we can turn part of our attention and effort to the active promotion of local enterprise. Perhaps the Government can help identify and preserve limited areas of economic activity which local enterprise and capital can be encouraged to go into or develop.

    Sir, in the President's speech he lamented the recent financial coup achieved by a foreign company. May I ask the Minister for Finance whether, and what, measures are being considered to prevent a repetition of the incident?

4.24 p.m.

    The Minister of State for Foreign Affairs (Inche A. Rahim Ishak): Mr Speaker, Sir, as 1971 comes to a close five months from today, Singapore, for the first time in its history, will no longer have the defence umbrella to which it has grown accustomed for the last 150 years. We shall, despite the Five-Power Defence arrangement, have to be more self- reliant.

    As was stated in the Addendum to the Presidential Address at the opening of the Second Session of the Second Parliament on the 21st of July, Singapore's foreign policy in the years ahead will have to be more outward-looking than it has hitherto been, because, among other things, external developments will be more directly felt by us. Singapore, by virtue of its size, cannot expect to influence international events. And precisely because of our small size and our inability to influence world

Column: 89

events, we might have become inward-looking as well as insular in our concept and practice of diplomacy.

    With the rapidly changing international scene in the Pacific and Indian Oceans, we have to develop the capacity to play our role in international affairs by involving ourselves in intra-regional or sub-regional developments. We can no longer think of our own individual and national interests as the powers and super-powers around us make new moves, and take on new alignments. We are realistic enough to know that international politics on a global scale is the art of the possible. And in line with this view, we shall participate in international politics wherever and whenever it is judicious and possible to do so, bearing in mind our own interests and those of our immediate neighbours.

    Regardless of the above, there is, however, one contribution Singapore can make in a positive way in international relations. This is to create a progressive, dynamic and successful society, by registering successes in our own internal development programmes and thereby influencing other states and societies by sheer force of example. At the same time, our growing prosperity and continued viability will ensure a self-confidence generated by our capacity to solve our own internal economic and social problems. With this, we hope to be a positive force in the international sphere in the hope that we would be freer to order the kind of life, which we think, is best for our people. In other words, we hope that non-interference in the affairs of other nations, which we believe in, will similarly be practised by others in their attitudes towards us.

    From experience in international politics, we know that in many cases if the big powers want to solve international problems, irrespective of whether they are in the Middle East, Indochina or Africa, they can solve them. But, all too often, it appears as if the big powers sometimes have an interest in not solving them, or in delaying their solutions. In this regard, it is clear to us in Singapore that the big powers in many cases want to make

Column: 90

use of small states as weights in the international daching. Where we are convinced that the big powers are so motivated, we shall, to the best of our ability, avoid any kind of involvement. But where we feel that such activities are detrimental to our own national interests, we shall counter any moves, which will compromise our independence and integrity.

    Although we have been independent for only six years, we have learned the bitter truth that it would be disastrous for small countries to act like major powers on the world stage, particularly if they do not have the capacity to do so. Therefore, to force ourselves on to the world stage without really understanding the aims and objectives of the producers and directors of the current play being performed, would mean breaking our backs and seriously injuring ourselves. Events in the Middle East, Indochina and other parts of Asia and Africa have persistently shown that the big powers want us to declare that we are on their side in big power conflicts. This we have refrained and must refrain from doing in the future.

    President Nixon's move as announced on the 16th July will, I think, lead to the establishment of relations with the People's Republic of China. This development is historically inevitable. The United States can no longer ignore the political and legal existence of China, just as China has to recognise -
